page.title: 12SS Godspeed
page.content: They cast off the moorings and the tiny{three-masted barque,}only 20m long, sailed from Ipswich on the early tide. It was 8.0am the first day of term, not{1606}when Captain Gosnold and a crew of 13 set sail for{Virginia with 39 emigrants (how ever did they squeeze in; live pigs and hens too!). We departed for school (hardship) but they were at sea for 5 months; trapped in the Channel by adverse wind for six weeks, they completed the{6000 mile journey in April 1607 just in time to sow their first crops. They were weak from bad food, they caught{cholera and {ague,}and almost 50% died by autumn, the Captain among them. But survivors did found the very first successful English 'plantation' in the New World. P.S. The{replica Godspeed}did not reach Jamestown by July; the Caribbean {hurricane season}halted the voyage.
